questions.text:
A 52-year-old male presents with worsening shortness of breath and fatigue. An echocardiogram shows left ventricular dilation and significant aortic regurgitation. Which of the following are the possible conditions causing Aortic regurgitation?


	Ankylosing Spondylitis
	Aortic Dissection
	Marfan's Syndrome
	Syphilis
questions.solution:
All of the above are potential causes of aortic regurgitation but through different mechanisms.

Aortic Regurgitation

Aetiology

Conditions affecting the valve structure and its functions

Conditions causing valve root dilatation
  • Bicuspid Aortic valve (Congenital)
  • Infective Endocarditis
  • Rheumatic fever
  • Myxomatous prolapse of the valve
  • Scarring of the valve by Syphilis (statement 4)
  • Ankylosing spondylitis (statement 1)
  • Radiation
  • Trauma
  • Aortic Dissection (statement 2)
  • Aortitis (Takayasu arteritis or GCA)
  • Hypertension
  • Marfan syndrome (statement 3)
  • Medial Degeneration
  • Nonsyndromic familial aneurysm

Pathophysiology

Clinical symptoms
  • Usually, it starts appearing only after 10 to 15 years.
  • Symptoms specific to AR:
    • Palpitations (more in the supine position)
    • Head pounding sensation
  • Other symptoms:
    • Paroxysmal Nocturnal dyspnea (sometimes the early one to appear)
    • Angina on rest or exertion & breathlessness on exertion
    • Orthopnea and diaphoresis
    • Peripheral edema

questions.text:
Match the following murmurs with the respective conditions.

 


	
		
			
			S.No
			
			
			Murmur
			
			
			Condition
			
		
		
			
			1)
			
			
			
			
			
			a) Mitral Stenosis
			
		
		
			
			2)
			
			
			
			b) Aortic Stenosis
			
		
		
			
			3)
			
			
			
			c) Mitral Regurgitation
			
		
		
			
			4)
			
			
			
			d) Aortic Regurgitation
questions.solution:
Aortic Stenosis:

  • Crescendo-decrescendo ejection murmur

Mitral/Tricuspid Regurgitation:

  • Holosystolic, high-pitched “blowing” murmur

 

Aortic Regurgitation:

  • Early diastolic, decrescendo, high-pitched “blowing” murmur

Mitral Stenosis:

  • Delayed rumbling mid-to-late diastolic murmur with opening snap

Mitral valve prolapse:

  • Late crescendo murmur with mid systolic click (MC) that occurs after carotid pulse

Ventricular septal defect:

  • Holosystolic, harsh-sounding murmur

questions.text: A 25 year old woman diagnosed with scleroderma presents with exertional dyspnea. You auscultate a high-pitched, decrescendo diastolic murmur at the second left intercostal space, radiating along the left sternal border that increases with inspiration. Which of the following is correct about this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a Scleroderma patient with h/o pulmonary hypertension & a high-pitched, decrescendo diastolic murmur heard at the second left intercostal space, radiating along the left sternal border that becomes louder with inspiration indicates a Graham steel murmur.

Graham Steel Murmur Features: 

  • High-pitched, decrescendo diastolic murmur is best heard at the second left intercostal space and radiates along the left sternal border.
  • Occurs due to pulmonary regurgitation due to pulmonary artery hypertension.
  • It can become louder with inspiration

Austin Flint Murmur (Option B):

  • Soft, low-pitched, rumbling mid-to-late diastolic murmur produced by the diastolic displacement of the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve due to the aortic regurgitation.
  • Not indicative of hemodynamically significant mitral valve obstruction.

Carey-Coombs Murmur (Option C):

  • Mid-diastolic murmur is commonly heard in cases of acute rheumatic fever, likely due to flow through an edematous mitral valve
  • Disappears with resolution of the acute episode.


Gibson murmur (Option D): It is a continuous, rumbling heart murmur that's usually heard in the second left interspace near the sternum & often seen in patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of left arm pain and intermittent dizziness. O/E, you find a notable difference in blood pressure readings: 150/90 mmHg in the right arm and 100/60 mmHg in the left arm. Which condition is least likely to cause this variation?
questions.solution:
Supravalvular aortic stenosis is at  sinotubular junction , meaning just before the aortic arch branches.  Hence blood supply to both right brachiocephalic trunk and left common carotid artery will be reduced equally. 

Coarctation of the Aorta (CoA) (Option A) typically causes lower blood pressure in the lower extremities compared to the upper extremities, but can also lead to differences between arms due to collateral circulation.

Aortic Dissection (Option B) can cause differences in blood pressure between arms if the dissection extends into the subclavian arteries or affects the branches that supply the arms.

Takayasu Arteritis (Option D) is an inflammatory condition that often affects the aorta and its branches and may cause stenosis or occlusion leading to differences in blood pressure between the arms.

questions.text:
Match the following cardiac valvular disorders with their specific murmur type:

 


	
		
			
			Valvular defect 
			
			
			Murmur 
			
		
		
			
			1. Aortic stenosis
			
			
			a. Pansystolic murmur increasing with inspiration
			
		
		
			
			2. Mitral regurgitation
			
			
			b. Mid-diastolic rumble with opening snap
			
		
		
			
			3. Mitral stenosis
			
			
			c. Harsh systolic murmur radiating to the carotids
			
		
		
			
			4. Tricuspid regurgitation
			
			
			d. Holosystolic murmur radiating to the axilla
questions.solution:
Valvular disease

Most common cause

ECG findings

JVP findings

Type of murmur

Specific features

Mitral regurgitation

  • Rheumatic heart disease
  • Degenerative
  • Atrial fibrillation may be present
  • P-mitrale > 120 seconds (enlarged left atrium)



 

Changes are seen only in advanced cases.

Holosystolic murmur radiating to the axilla.
  • Wide variable splitting of S2
  • A2 appears early as less blood is flowing through the aortic valve; thus, the S2 split is wide

Mitral stenosis

Rheumatic heart disease

Right axis deviation

RV hypertrophy.

Mid-diastolic rumble with an opening snap.

Loud S1

Malar rash

Distended neck veins

Tricuspid stenosis

Rheumatic

(coexist with mitral stenosis)

  

Tall P waves in the lead II

Right axis deviation

Large ‘a’ wave

Blunted ‘y’ wave

Mid-diastolic murmur

Carvallo’s sign

Tricuspid regurgitation

Rheumatic

‘C-v’ wave

Steep ‘y’ descent

Blowing holosystolic murmur

Systolic liver pulsation

 

Carvallo’s sign

Aortic regurgitation

  • Infective endocarditis
  • Bicuspid aortic valve

Left axis deviation

LV hypertrophy

Changes are seen only in advanced cases

Decrescendo diastolic murmur
  • Wide pulse pressure
  • Water hammer pulse
 

Aortic stenosis

Degenerative calcification

53% of cases have congenital bicuspid aortic valve

Accentuated “a” wave due to reduced RV cavity distensibility from the hypertrophied interventricular septum

Crescendo-decrescendo ejection murmur.

Gallavardin effect

Pulmonary regurgitation

Pulmonary hypertension

  

Right axis deviation

RV hypertrophy.

  

Large ‘a’ wave

End–diastolic murmur

(Graham Steel murmur)

Cardiac MRI is the IOC rather than echocardiography

Pulmonary stenosis

Congenital defect

Systolic ejection murmur

Wide split S2

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl with a history of Tetralogy of Fallot repair 12 months ago presents with abdominal swelling and pedal oedema. Cardiac auscultation reveals an early diastolic murmur, and ECG shows right ventricular and atrial enlargement. Considering the suspicion of pulmonary regurgitation, which investigation is most appropriate for further evaluation?
questions.solution:
Cardiac MRI is the investigation of choice to diagnose pulmonary regurgitation, especially in patients with repaired congenital heart defects, as it provides more anatomical details and helps precisely access the Right ventricular volume and function.

PULMONARY REGURGITATION

Aetiology

  • Pulmonary artery hypertension - annular dilatation of the pulmonary valve
  • Post-repair of Tetralogy of Fallot
  • Post balloon valvotomy
  • Marfan syndrome

Pathophysiology

  • Severe pulmonary regurgitation (PR) results in right ventricular enlargement and eccentric hypertrophy due to increased preload and afterload.
  • A reverse pressure gradient from the pulmonary artery to the right ventricle drives the regurgitation, leading to a reduction in cardiac output over time.
  • As the condition progresses, right atrial involvement may occur, elevating jugular venous pressure.

Clinical features

  • Fatigue, dyspnea, ascites, and pedal oedema
  • Auscultation reveals an early diastolic murmur (Graham steel murmur)

Investigations

  • Chest X-ray: Enlarged right atrium and ventricular shadow
  • Cardiac MRI: Investigation of choice, especially in patients with repaired congenital heart defects.
  • Echocardiography (transthoracic): It helps assess pulmonary valve morphology and the direction of blood flow. (Option A and C)
  • Cardiac catheterisation is not usually done but can be done during transcatheter pulmonary valve procedures. (Option D)

Treatment

  • Medical: Diuretics for symptoms of right-sided heart failure
  • Surgical: Transcatheter pulmonic valve replacement.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old girl presents with exercise intolerance and occasional chest pain. Examination reveals a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border and elevated jugular venous pressure. An echocardiogram shows a peak systolic gradient of 70 mmHg across the pulmonary valve, raising suspicion for pulmonary valve stenosis. Which of the following set of statements is true regarding this condition?


	Pulmonic stenosis is always congenital.
	Dysplastic valves leading to pulmonary stenosis are seen in Noonan syndrome.
	Severe PS is defined by peak systolic gradient across the PV>64 mmHg
	Percutaneous balloon valvuloplasty is indicated for all patients.
	Pulmonic stenosis usually leads to right ventricular hypertrophy.
questions.solution:
Pulmonary stenosis can involve dysplastic valves in Noonan syndrome. It is considered severe when the peak systolic gradient exceeds 64 mmHg and typically leads to right ventricular hypertrophy due to pressure overload.

PULMONARY STENOSIS

Aetiology

It is essentially a congenital disease, but it may be acquired (Statement 1 ruled out)

  • Noonan syndrome (dysplastic pulmonary valve) (Statement 2)
  • Tetralogy of Fallot
  • Carcinoids
  • Bulky vegetation or tumours

Pathophysiology

  • Pulmonary stenosis obstructs blood flow from the right ventricle, resulting in increased chamber pressure and subsequent right ventricular hypertrophy. (Statement 5)
  • Right ventricular dysfunction occurs early and at lower pressures due to its reduced adaptability to hemodynamic burden compared to the left ventricle.

Severity

Defined by the systolic pressure gradient between the RV and PA

  • Severe: Peak systolic gradient >64 mm hg (Statement 3)
  • Moderate: Peak systolic gradient 36-64 mm hg
  • Mild: Peak systolic gradient <36 hh mg

Clinical features

  • Mild to moderate PS are asymptomatic.
  • Severe PS: Exertional dyspnea, fatigue, anginal pain and systemic venous congestion
  • Syncope may occur during stress.
  • Auscultation: Mid-systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur preceded by an ejection click.
  • JVP: Prominent ‘a’ wave

Investigations

  • ECG: Right axis deviation + Right ventricular hypertrophy
  • Chest X-ray: Post-stenotic dilation of the main PA and RV enlargement.
  • Echocardiography:
    • Transthoracic: Helps assess jet velocity, gradients, ventricular function
    • Transesophageal (for detailed assessment of RV outflow tract)

Management

  • Medical: Diuretics for symptoms of right-sided heart failure
  • Surgical: Percutaneous pulmonary balloon valvuloplasty (Statement 4 ruled out) is done when
    • Symptomatic patients with moderate to severe PS
    • Asymptomatic patients with peak gradient >64 mmHg or mean gradient > 35 mmHg.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male with a history of long-standing hypertension and atrial fibrillation presents with progressive fatigue & bilateral leg swelling. O/E, the patient has distended neck veins with the following waveform with a blowing holosystolic murmur that increases with inspiration. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is likely tricuspid regurgitation, as the patient presents with jugular venous distension (prominent C-V waves, rapid Y descent), ascites, and hepatomegaly. The characteristic finding is a blowing holosystolic murmur at the lower left sternal border, which increases with inspiration.

Pulmonary hypertension (Option A) can cause right-sided heart failure, but it does not typically present with a holosystolic murmur or intensification of the murmur with inspiration. Instead, the primary finding is a loud P2 sound due to increased pressure in the pulmonary arteries.

Pulmonary stenosis (Option C) presents with an ejection systolic murmur heard best over the pulmonic area, not a holosystolic murmur, and does not typically intensify with inspiration.

Mitral regurgitation (Option D) causes a holosystolic murmur, which is best heard at the apex and radiates to the axilla. As it involves the left side of the heart, mitral regurgitation does not intensify with inspiration, and the jugular venous findings are not typical of left-sided heart disease.

questions.text: A 66-year-old female presents with fatigue, abdominal discomfort, and swelling in her legs. On examination, she has jugular venous distention with giant ‘a’ waves, hepatomegaly, and ascites. Auscultation reveals a diastolic murmur at the lower left sternal border, which increases in intensity with inspiration. What’s the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The diastolic murmur at the lower left sternal border that increases with inspiration, along with jugular venous distention with giant ‘a’ waves, hepatomegaly, and ascites, is suggestive of Tricuspid stenosis.
  • This condition is characterised by restricted blood flow from the right atrium to the right ventricle, often leading to right-sided heart failure symptoms like swelling in the legs, abdominal discomfort, and hepatomegaly.
  • The presence of a diastolic murmur at the lower left sternal border further supports the diagnosis.

 

Pathophysiology

Mitral stenosis (MS) (Option A) causes left atrial pressure overload, leading to pulmonary congestion and dyspnea, often with orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. This patient’s presentation is dominated by right-sided heart failure symptoms (ascites, hepatomegaly, oedema) without the significant pulmonary congestion typically seen in MS.

Constrictive pericarditis (Option C) causes a thickened, non-compliant pericardium, limiting diastolic filling and leading to systemic venous congestion (jugular venous distension, hepatomegaly, ascites). Heart sounds may be muffled, and a pericardial knock can be present. Unlike tricuspid stenosis, constrictive pericarditis lacks a diastolic murmur.

Aortic stenosis (Option D) causes left ventricular outflow obstruction, leading to exertional dyspnea, angina, and syncope, with a systolic ejection murmur radiating to the carotids. This patient's right-sided heart failure and diastolic murmur are more consistent with tricuspid stenosis, not aortic stenosis.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man presents with severe aortic regurgitation. He reports increasing fatigue, breathlessness, and episodes of dizziness. On auscultation, a diastolic murmur is heard along with a water-hammer pulse, and an echocardiogram shows significant left ventricular dilation and an ejection fraction of 55%. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Aortic valve replacement is the ideal management for severe aortic regurgitation patients who are symptomatic, irrespective of their LV function.
  • In asymptomatic progressive aortic regurgitation, AVR is advisable if LV dysfunction is evident.
  • Regular non-invasive follow-up, once in 6-12 months, is necessary to monitor the development of myocardial dysfunction, as surgery delayed long after its development has minimal chances of completing LV recovery.

 

Work up for Aortic regurgitation

Investigations

Findings

ECG
  • LV Hypertrophy
  • Left axis deviation is noted
  • QRS prolongation is seen occasionally
  • LV Strain - ST wave depression and T wave inversion in I, aVL, V5, V6 leads

Chest X-ray
  • Inferolateral displacement of the apex is noted
  • Aortic root dilation, often associated with aortic regurgitation, can be visible on a lateral chest X-ray as it fills the retrosternal space.
  • It is not very sensitive to Aortic root conditions

Echocardiogram
  • Rapid fluttering of the anterior mitral valve during diastole because of the regurgitation.
  • A dilated left ventricle is noted.
  • It is the investigation of choice in Severe AR

Cardiac Catheterization and Angiography

(Occasionally done)
  • To evaluate the LV function and regurgitation
  • Done before surgery, but CT angiography can be done instead.


 

Management

Type

Acute AR

Chronic AR

Medical

(Option A)
  • IV Diuretics (Furosemide) and Vasodilators (Sodium Nitroprusside) are used to stabilise the patient.
  • Beta Blockers are contraindicated as they worsen the symptoms and reduce the cardiac output.
  • Diuretics and Vasodilators like
    • ACEi, CCB,
    • Hydralazine,
    • ARBs (can be used in chronic AR) to manage HTN; Target SBP <140 mm/Hg.
  • For Angina: Nitrates
  • For Syphilis: Benzathine Penicillin, 2.4 million units IM, three doses given with one week gap.

Surgical

  • Aortic valve replacement (AVR) is the treatment of choice, usually within 24 hours of diagnosis.
  • Intra-Aortic Balloon pump is contraindicated as it worsens the regurgitant flow. (Option C)
  • AVR is indicated when developing LV dysfunction or symptoms.
  • Transcatheter aortic valve implantation (Option B) is not suggested due to its limited success in chronic conditions.

questions.text:
Match the following signs with specific features


	
		
			
			Signs
			
			
			Features
			
		
		
			
			1. Muller Sign
			
			
			a) Systolic pulsations of the Spleen
			
		
		
			
			2. Rosenbach sign
			
			
			b) Visible systolic pulsation of the uvula
			
		
		
			
			3. Gerhardt's sign
			
			
			c) Jarring motion of the head with each heartbeat
			
		
		
			
			4. De-Musset sign
			
			
			d) Systolic pulsations of the Liver
questions.solution:
Signs of Aortic Regurgitation

Muller Sign

It is a visible systolic pulsation of the uvula

Rosenbach sign

Systolic pulsations of the Liver

Gerhardt's sign

Systolic pulsations of the Spleen

Quincke's sign

Repeatedly alternating blushing and blanching of capillaries in the nail folds upon palpation (Capillary Pulsations)

Landolphi sign

Alternating systolic constriction and diastolic dilatation of pupils

Traube Sign

It is pistol shot sounds that are heard while auscultating over the femoral artery.

Water-Hammer pulse

Strong pulse that rises quickly and then drops off suddenly.

Duroziez Sign

It is a to-and-fro murmur heard while auscultating the femoral artery.

De-Musset sign

The jarring motion of the head with each heartbeat

 

Examination Findings of Aortic Regurgitation

Blood Pressure
  • Elevated systolic pressure and decreased diastolic pressure result in increased arterial pulse pressure.
  • Atrio-ventricular malformation and Atrio-ventricular ﬁstula also show low diastolic BP due to continuous Korotkoﬀ sounds.
  • Positive Hill’s sign is an abnormal difference in BP in the upper limb and lower limb.

On Palpation
  • Heaving LV impulse is noted, which is displaced laterally and inferiorly
  • Diastolic and Systolic Thrills were noticed at the left lower sternal border and suprasternal notch, respectively.

On Auscultation

  

Heart Sounds
  • A2 is absent
  • In the Bicuspid aortic valve, systolic ejection sound is present
  • Sometimes, A4 is also heard

Murmurs
  • A Decrescendo diastolic murmur, best heard when sitting up and leaning forward, is an early diastolic murmur that becomes holo-diastolic as the condition progresses to a severe stage.
  • Musical diastolic murmur is aortic cusp fluttering in the regurgitant flow.
  • Mid-diastolic murmur
  • Austin Flint murmur is a soft, low-pitched, mid- to end-diastolic murmur caused by mitral valve displacement due to AR.
  • Ejection systolic murmur is commonly heard in AR along with AS.

questions.text: A 72-year-old male presents with complaints of worsening dyspnea, angina and orthopnea. Physical examination reveals a loud diastolic murmur at the left sternal border and a widened pulse pressure. An echocardiogram indicates significant left ventricular dilation. What is the likely estimated regurgitant volume in this condition to label as severe valvular dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Widened pulse pressure with diastolic murmur with the given symptom profile points to Aortic regurgitation. The tregurgitant volume in a patient with severe aortic regurgitation exceeds 60 mL per beat. 

 

Echocardiogram Findings for Aortic Regurgitation

Severe Aortic regurgitation

Progressive Aortic regurgitation
  • Regurgitant Volume is > 60 ml/beat
  • Regurgitant fraction is ≥50%
  • Holodiastolic aortic flow reversal - blood flows backwards into the left ventricle throughout the diastolic phase.
  • Diastolic flow reversal in the descending aorta.
  • Ejection Fraction is 55 - 60 %
  • Left ventricle end-systolic dimension (LVESD) is >50 mm
  • Left ventricle end-diastolic dimension

(LVEDD) is > 65 mm

 

Acute Aortic Regurgitation

Chronic Aortic Regurgitation
  • It is a sudden onset of significant backflow from the aorta into the left ventricle, causing LV dilatation.
  • This leads to pulmonary oedema, which can progress to acute heart failure.
  • The presence of a water-hammer pulse/Corrigan’s pulse is a strong pulse that rises quickly and then drops off suddenly.
  • Quincke's pulse (Capillary pulsations)
  • The Frank-Starling law explains that blood flowing back into the left ventricle increases its contractions due to stretching of the ventricle walls.
  • Reduced Cardiac output at rest.
  • Both Preload and Afterload are increased (Laplace law)
  • LVH is common.
  • High myocardial oxygen demand can lead to Myocardial ischemia.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with palpitations, chest discomfort, and fatigue. A mid-systolic click and late systolic murmur are heard at the apex. Echocardiography shows mitral valve leaflets billowing into the left atrium during systole. Which of the following is leading cause of this presentation?

choices.text: Inflammation of the mitral valve due to rheumatic fever
Fibrotic changes affecting the mitral valves
Rupture of the tendinae of the mitral valve
Myxomatous degeneration of mitral valve apparatus.

questions.solution:
Myxomatous degeneration of the mitral valve apparatus leads to mitral valve leaflets billowing into the left atrium during systole, thus causing Mitral valve prolapse.

 

MITRAL VALVE PROLAPSE

Aetiology

  • Most cases are idiopathic
  • Myxomatous degeneration of the mitral valve apparatus (Reduced type III collagen production)
  • Marfan syndrome (Fibrillin-1 protein defect)
  • Ehler Danlos syndrome
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta
  • Straight back syndrome (reduced thoracic kyphosis) compresses the heart between the sternum and vertebrae, altering its position and increasing the likelihood of mitral valve prolapse (MVP).

Pathophysiology

Clinical features

  • Incidence
    • More in females: 15-30 years
    • Males: 50 years
  • Severity: More severe in men than women
  • Symptoms:
    • Initially asymptomatic
    • Palpitation and syncope due to premature ventricular contraction.
    • Atypical features
      • Substernal pain without exertion.
      • Transient ischemic attack.
      • Risk of endocarditis and Sudden cardiac death.
      • If Mitral regurgitation (MR) occurs, it can lead to increased pressure in the lungs, causing frank pulmonary oedema.

 

Auscultation findings of Mitral valve prolapse

  • Mid or late non-ejection systolic click
  • High-pitched mid-late systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the apex.

 

Change in auscultation findings with change in cavity size

Condition

Valsalva or Sudden Standing

Squatting, Leg Raising, Standing to Supine, Isometric Exercises

Preload and Afterload

↓

↑

Cavity size

↓

↑

Chordae tendineae stretching

↓

↑

Timing of click

The click occurs earlier, closer to S1

The click occurs later, away from S1

Murmur duration

↑

↓


 

Inflammation of the mitral valve due to rheumatic fever (Option A) occurs in Rheumatic heart disease, which can result in fibrotic changes in the mitral valve (Option B), leading to mitral stenosis, which produces a low-pitched diastolic rumble.


Rupture of the tendinae of the mitral valve (Option C) leads to acute severe mitral regurgitation, which can be a complication of mitral valve prolapse but is not the cause.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman reports experiencing mild chest pain and shortness of breath on exertion. On examination, harsh  ejection- systolic murmur is noted, best heard at the right second intercostal space and radiating to the carotids. An Echocardiogram shows an aortic valve area of 0.9 cm². Which stage of aortic stenosis is present and what is the ideal management?
questions.solution:
Aortic Valve area of < 1 cm² (Severe Stenosis) along with symptoms are categorized into Stage D and is managed by Transcatheter Aortic Valve Replacement (TAVR).

Stage

Aortic Valve area

Explanation

Stage A

Normal

Patient with normal aortic valve functioning and presence of risk factors like:

  • Old age
  • Congenital valvular disease
  • History of rheumatic fever
  • History of endocarditis
  • Genetic Polymorphisms
  • HTN, DM, CKD, Smoking & High LDL.
 

Stage B

1.5 - 2 cm² (Mild)

It involves asymptomatic patients with mild to moderate stenosis.

1 - 1.5 cm² (Moderate)

Stage C

< 1 cm²

Asymptomatic severe aortic stenosis

Stage D

< 1 cm²

Symptomatic severe aortic stenosis

Patients with aortic stenosis are typically managed medically unless they are symptomatic, with a few exceptions.

Stage/Condition

Management

Asymptomatic with HTN or CAD

Start ACE inhibitors or beta-blockers.

Stage B
  • Consider TAVR if LVEF < 60% (based on three readings).
  • Regular monitoring with Doppler echocardiogram every 1-2 years to evaluate progression.

Stage C
  • Avoid strenuous exercise, hypovolemia, and dehydration to maintain adequate cardiac output.
  • Indications for TAVR:
    • LVEF < 50%.
    • Ejection velocity > 5 m/sec.
    • Transvalvular gradient (LV-AO) > 60 mmHg.
  • Statins should be started to prevent the progression of atherosclerosis.

Stage D
  • TAVR is indicated.
  • For pediatric patients with congenital aortic stenosis, aortic balloon valvuloplasty is the preferred treatment.

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient presents with angina and shortness of breath on exertion. Physical examination reveals a slow-rising carotid pulse and a systolic ejection murmur.  Which of the following is most likely to be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Aortic stenosis has slow rising anacortic pulse with ejection systolic murmur. It is seen in geriatric population and hence these patients have co-existent triple vessel disease. Left atrial hypertrophy causing double apical impulse will be seen in these patients. Note that hypertrophy causes lateral displacement of apex beat and not medial. 

 

Must know findings of aortic stenosis 

Carotid Pulse

Characterized by a slow rise and delayed peak (pulsus parvus et tardus/Anacrotic pulse)

  • A thrill or anacrotic “shudder” may be felt over the carotid arteries, often more prominent on the left

JVP
  • Accentuated “a” wave due to reduced right ventricular (RV) cavity distensibility from the hypertrophied interventricular septum.

LV Impulse
  • Lateral displacement in advanced stages.
  • A double apical impulse and palpable S4 may be noted, especially in the left lateral recumbent position.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents to the clinic with increasing fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. O/E a harsh, systolic crescendo-decrescendo ejection murmur is noted at the right second intercostal space. Which of the following is not seen in this condition ?
questions.solution:
• The clinical scenario described indicates case of Aortic stenosis, characterized by a harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo ejection murmur typically heard at the right second intercostal space.
  • Water hammer pulse is seen in Aortic regurgitation while Aortic stenosis has anacrotic pulse. Left axis deviation is seen in AS due to concentric left ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents with fatigue and progressive shortness of breath, particularly when climbing stairs. During the physical examination, a harsh, systolic ejection murmur is heard at the right second intercostal space, radiating to the carotids. Which of the following factors is least likely to be associated with the development of the condition?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario with systolic ejection murmur heard at the right second intercostal space radiating to the carotids suggests Aortic Stenosis.
  • While mediastinal irradiation, mutation in NOTCH1, and prior rheumatic inflammation are all factors associated with aortic valve dysfunction.
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus is less directly linked to the development of Aortic Stenosis.

 

Etiology of Aortic stenosis (AS):

Degenerative Calcification

The primary cause of aortic stenosis (AS) in adults, often due to:

  • Congenital Bicuspid Aortic Valve (BAV): Approximately 53% of cases.
  • Trileaflet Valve Deterioration
  • Previous Rheumatic Fever (Option C ruled out): Inflammation can lead to scarring and calcification.

Rheumatic Heart Disease 

It causes commissural fusion, resembling BAV, and leads to valve narrowing.

Mediastinal Radiation (Option A ruled out)

Cause late scarring and calcification of the aortic leaflets.

Shone Complex

Components include Aortic stenosis, Coarctation of aorta, Parachute mitral valve, supravalvular mitral membrane

Genetic polymorphisms
  • Vitamin D receptor
  • Estrogen receptor (notably in postmenopausal women)
  • Interleukin 10
  • Apolipoprotein E4

Traditional risk factors

Hypertension, High LDL, Smoking, DM, CKD

Bicuspid Aortic Valve Disease
  • Most common congenital heart valve defect, with a male predominance (2–4:1).
  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant with incomplete penetrance
  • Genetic Factors: Mutations in NOTCH1 (Option B ruled out), GATA5, and GATA4 have been noted

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with recurrent syncopal episodes. On examination pulse is 60/min, regular with BP 140/100 mm Hg. Auscultation reveals ejection systolic murmur is heard at the right second intercostal space and radiates to the carotids. The murmur also becomes higher-pitched when heard at the apex. ECG shows left axis deviation with normal sinus rythm.  Which condition is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of Syncopal episodes with Ejection systolic murmur in geriatric age group points to valvular aortic stenosis. 

  • The ejection systolic murmur of aortic stenosis has two components:

    1. Low-frequency, harsh component – heard at right upper sternal border (RUSB)

    2. High-frequency musical component – transmitted to the apex = Gallavardin phenomenon / effect 

  • Sick sinus syndrome and Stokes adam syndrome are ruled out as ECG shows normal sinus rythm. 

 

Gallavardin Effect:

  • It refers to the phenomenon where a murmur of aortic stenosis (AS) becomes higher-pitched and more acoustically pure when auscultated at the apex of the heart despite originating from the aortic region.
  • The ejection (mid) systolic (Crescendo-decrescendo) murmur of AS typically starts shortly after S1, increases in intensity, peaks during ejection, and ends just before aortic valve closure.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient presents with exertional dyspnea and a history of rheumatic fever. Echocardiogram shows severe mitral stenosis with calcification. Which of the following is the most appropriate management strategy for her condition?
questions.solution:
Mitral valve replacement is indicated for significant symptoms in patients with calcified severe mitral stenosis, particularly when heavy calcification makes the valve unsuitable for balloon valvuloplasty.

Procedure

Indications / Requirements

Mitral Balloon Valvuloplasty (PMBC) (Option B ruled out)
  • Significant symptoms present
  • Isolated mitral stenosis (no or trivial mitral regurgitation)
  • Mobile, non-calcified valve/sub valve apparatus on echocardiogram
  • Left atrium free of thrombus

Surgical Commissurotomy
  • Required if PMBC fails
  • Involves opening valve commissures and addressing subvalvular structures

Mitral Valve Replacement (Option C)
  • Substantial mitral regurgitation
  • Rigid and calcified valve
  • Presence of thrombus formation


 

Mitral Balloon Valvuloplasty/Percutaneous Mitral Balloon Commissurotomy:

questions.text: A 48-year-old female presents with worsening exertional dyspnea and fatigue. She has a history of rheumatic fever during her childhood. Examination shows diastolic murmur at the cardiac apex with pronounced opening snap. Which of the following findings is least likely to be present in this case?
questions.solution:
• Heaving apex beat is seen in Aortic stenosis. Mitral stenosis has a tapping apex beat
  • The clinical scenario of worsening exertional dyspnea, a history of rheumatic fever, and the presence of a diastolic murmur with an opening snap suggests Mitral stenosis & the primary issue is obstruction, leading to left atrial enlargement and a reduced mitral valve area
  • Long standing MS will cause Pulmonary artery hypertension. That explains development of right ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with a history of rheumatic heart disease comes to the OPD for a regular follow-up. Echocardiography confirmed the presence of severe mitral regurgitation . When considering her treatment options, which of the following interventions should not be included in her management plan?

choices.text: Use of Apixaban if her CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥2
Mitral valve repair if ejection fraction falls less than 60%

questions.solution:
• In patients with RHD with vavlvular lesions, Vitamin K antagonists (VKAs) like warfarin are the preferred anticoagulants for preventing thromboembolic events, particularly if atrial fibrillation is present.
  • Non-vitamin K oral anticoagulants (NOACs) like apixaban are generally not recommended for patients with rheumatic mitral valve disease, as these agents have not been well studied or proven to be safe and effective in this population.
  • Surgical repair in asymptomatic patients must be done when EF<60% or LV ESD >= 40mm

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, shortness of breath on exertion, and palpitations. On physical examination, a systolic thrill is palpable at the cardiac apex. Echocardiography showed severe backflow of blood from the left ventricle to the left atrium during ventricular systole. What kind of murmur is most likely to be heard during cardiac auscultation of this patient?

choices.text: An opening snap followed by a diastolic murmur
Holosystolic murmur, best heard at the apex
Crescendo decrescendo systolic murmur best heard at the base

questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and echocardiography show features of severe mitral regurgitation, so on cardiac auscultation, a holosystolic murmur will most likely be heard at the cardiac apex.

 

MITRAL REGURGITATION

Clinical examination

  • BP may be normal or ↓ ; Narrow pulse pressure.
  • Palpable thrill at the cardiac apex.
  • Hyperdynamic and laterally displaced apex beat.
  • Normal or ↑ JVP.

Auscultation findings

  • Soft or absent S1.
  • Wide variable splitting of S2: P2 is variable, and A2 appears early as less blood flows through the aortic valve; thus, the S2 split is wide.
  • S4 may be heard in acute severe MR.

Murmur
  • Holosystolic murmur in chronic MR. (High-pitched blowing murmur, radiating towards axilla)
  • A decrescendo early systolic murmur in acute severe MR.

 

 

Continuous murmurs (Option A) occur during both systole and diastole, which is not characteristic of mitral regurgitation. They are typically associated with conditions that involve persistent blood flow between high- and low-pressure areas, such as in patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), where there is a constant flow of blood between the aorta and pulmonary artery.

An opening snap followed by a diastolic murmur (Option B) is heard in mitral stenosis. It occurs due to the narrowed mitral valve opening during diastole, resulting in an opening snap followed by a low-pitched diastolic rumble.

Crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur (Option C) is typical of aortic stenosis. It is heard best at the base of the heart and radiates to the carotids. This murmur reflects the turbulent flow of blood through the narrowing of the aortic valve.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of primary chronic mitral regurgitation?
questions.solution:
Primary chronic mitral regurgitation (MR) refers to structural abnormalities of the mitral valve itself. Ischemic cardiomyopathy causes secondary (functional) mitral regurgitation due to left ventricular dilation or dysfunction, not a primary structural issue of the valve.

 

MITRAL REGURGITATION

Etiology

(Options B, C & D ruled out)

Pathophysiology

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic male with mitral valve prolapse presents with palpitations. Pulse 130/min irregular, BP on admission is 160/100 mmHg. He also has a history of infective endocarditis. Which of the following statements regarding his management is not true?

choices.text: Anticoagulation therapy should be avoided due to low CHADS2Vasc score
Beta-blockers should be initiated for his palpitations
Mitral valve repair is preferred over mitral valve replacement

questions.solution:
As the patient has a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 3. (Age, DM and HTN) anticoagulation therapy should be initiated to reduce the risk of cerebrovascular accident. Prophylactic Antibiotics are given if patient has previous history of infective endocarditis. Beta blockers will be useful for palpitations and patient should be scheduled for mitral valve prolapse repair to prevent further damage to left atria. Repair preserves the native valve, improves outcomes, and decreases postoperative complications. 

 

CHA2DS2-VASc: The CHA2DS2-VASc score is a clinical tool used to estimate the risk of stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation (AF) and to guide anticoagulation therapy.

  • Congestive heart failure (1 point)
  • Hypertension (1 point)
  • Age ≥ 75 years (2 points)
  • Diabetes mellitus (1 point)
  • Stroke/TIA/TE history (2 points)
  • Vascular disease (1 point)
  • Age 65-74 years (1 point)
  • Sex category (female sex, 1 point)

Scoring:

  • 0 points: Low risk (consider no anticoagulation)
  • 1 point: Moderate risk (consider anticoagulation, especially if female)
  • 2 or more points: High risk (anticoagulation recommended)
